comments.commentBody: Until the popular pressures from below force the ruling Saudi dynasty to undertake such democratic reforms as could widen popular participation in decision making and unshacle the society from the repressive tradition rooted in obscurantist social religious practices, the cosmetic reforms being pushed by the Deputy Crown Prince Salmon would mean nothing except a part of power struggle to gain supremacy.
Yeah, and the tie-in to the Sharks may be a good omen.

Martin,

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=X69P_Vce9vw

Alan's dad is no Sinatra, but this is the version I wore out as a kid. Sometimes less is more:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=m2T4-8VLq3s
Martin, I did the puzzle tonight while watching the game. Tis a far, far better thing what Montero did than he has ever done before.

Higher pays and bigger chances of advancedment could pay off when two conditions are met.

First, a pay rise is meaninful in relative terms, not absolute terms as time progresses.

The morale for employess is boosted when they are paid higher at their jobs than other similar jobs.

If they could get an equivalent pay at another job, they couldn't find any reason to work hard. That is, they could leave the job in favor of another one with a greater pay.

The implication is that job morale stimulating efficiency wage matters when it is bigger than on average and that, if average wage levels in an industry rise to a point of no significant differences, its impact could noticeably decline, with increased consumers prices levels.

Second, even if higer paid employees work hard, the resulting hike in sales and profit for employers is possible when the economy is high. In a slow economy, higher pays would put more of a burden on employers as the aggregate demand is meager.

So employers are tempted to downsize and cut payroll even if such action could trigger a vicious cycle of recession. After all, businesses are just profit maximizers, not a coordinator of macroeconomic order.

Finally, if a business is on the export side, raising pays for workers will be less likely. In a globalized cutthroat competition, price is often a determinant of competitveness, thus higher labor costs leading to higher prices, lower sales.

In short, the issue is really tough.

This kind of comparison has occurred to me as well. There are really too many points to compare--another that comes to mind is, what if Hillary Clinton dodged every question and criticism by bringing up an angry charge about her opponent's history? And never, ever, accepted the blame for anything?

Mr. Trump is old, old school. Instead of Mrs. Clinton's name, substitute the name of any modern male presidential candidate. Imagine the howls? Somehow, this man has tapped into an ugly American vein where his adherents will minimize and justify any behavior no matter how lurid. Still, others, will blindly vote Republican no matter what. Millions of Americans are voting for this lunatic. I say, Love it, or move back to Europe.

The fundamental illogic of arguing that the left and sane people in general have gotten more scared of a Trump presidency as his chances for victory (less than 20%) continue make him a long shot as the home stretch gets smaller and smaller speaks for itself.

Reagan didn't face an opposition that was nearly as obstructionist as Obama did.
good puzzle. gimmes include ibuprofen, tilted, near thing, Rosstti. Liked thistls and macaroon. Also wanted to put in meringue!

"First, serious religious conservatives didn’t want Trump."....Apparently there are not very many serious religious conservatives. What kind of seriously religious person would ever consider a vote for Donald Trump? And further more, no serious religious conservative would insist on shoving their interpretation of religion down their neighbors throat. Most of the people you classify as serious religious conservatives are nothing more than closet bigots, and they support Trump because he has opened the closet door.
Yeah, and the tie-in to the Sharks may be a good omen.

What on earth are you talking about? All presidents and presidential candidates get Secret Service protection. It's necessary. I have no objection to that regardless of which party the person belongs to, or whether I voted against that person, or whether the person is doing a good job. Respect the office.

Donald Trump is utterly and irremediably unfit and unqualified to be president, but he's the GOP nominee, so he gets the same protection any other candidate does. If, God help us, he became president, he would be entitled to the protection that comes with the office. It's our fault, the voters, if the person holding the office isn't worthy of it.
And diehard Sharks fans say their blood runs teal.

No, read the article again and actually compare the shade you throw on Hillary to Trump's actual record.  And of course, the notion that a former Sec of State and Senator who had been the spouse of a President and a lifetime of public service is only nominated because she is a woman is sexist baloney.

I hope you will take the time to answer my question. Do you believe that any, or all of your points, indicate that Hillary Clinton is a threat to our country's national security? If yes, why? If not, why?
Based on your own observations (exclude media reports), do you believe that what you have seen of, and heard from, Donald Trump for the past 18 months indicates that he is a threat to our country's national security? If yes, why? If not, why?
Thank you.

Because we still live in a very sexist,very artificially gender divided,gender stereotyped,woman-hating male dominated society and what is so incomprehensible is, men are born from and nurtured by *women* the very people they have been irrationally hating for 1000's of years! It's the equivalent of if Black people could give birth to and nurture white racist Klu Klux Klan members and Jews could give birth to and nurture Nazis!

Imagine if Trump called African American youth "super-predators" to help sell his administration's crime bill to the American people while first lady.

Imagine if Trump was selected to lead his new president's health care reform effort and with overwhelming Democratic majorities in both houses of congress he botched it--thanks to conducting what was described as a disastrously secretive process. Imagine if that failure helped bring about the rise of Newt Gingrich as the first GOP Speaker of the House in forty years.

Imagine if as a Senator, Trump had still voted for the Iraq War after being briefed by our intelligence services. And wrote no major legislation.

Imagine if Trump had relentlessly appealed to the white working class toto impede the nomination of Barack Obama.

Imagine if Trump while Secretary of State supported the removal of Qaddafi in Libya turning it into a hotbed of terrorism and refugee disaster that is helping destabilize Europe.

Imagine if after leaving a lifetime of government service, Trump created in a few short years a net worth of more than $100 million--much of it from sitting on corporate boards and speaking fees.

Imagine if $650,000 of Trump's new wealth came from making three speeches before investment bankers who nearly destroyed our financial system. And what if Trump refused to release the transcripts of what he said while claiming to be for "the people"?

What if Hillary Clinton wasn't a woman? Would she be Trump's opponent? You decide.

"The constant drumbeat of attacks on Planned Parenthood that threatens their services for cancer screening and contraceptive care discredits the "religious right"."

It wouldn't be that way if Planned Parenthood didn't receive taxpayer dollars. If PP is such a wonderful organization with millions of supporters, they should't get a single dime from the Treasury.

The religious right has no objection to public funding for contraceptive services. The religious right objects to forcing the Little Sisters to pay for them.

Planned Parenthood does not provide any cancer screenings. What they do is take federal Medicaid dollars, skim off a substantial percentage for overhead to subsidize abortion services, and pay the balance to outside laboratories and clinics to conduct cancer screenings.

The opposition to abortion by the religious right would be more acceptable and understandable by the left if the religious right was not so opposed to funding for contraceptive services to prevent unwanted pregnancies.

The constant drumbeat of attacks on Planned Parenthood that threatens their services for cancer screening and contraceptive care discredits the "religious right".

Another aspect is that there is little attention paid to the "religious left": those who do not view abortion and contraception as the most serious issues facing this nation, but are concerned with income inequality and climate change.

I have to disagree with your opening sentence. Michelle was right.

There's a difference between a groundswell of disgust among men, which I agree does exist, and a breadth and depth of disgust which your own words demonstrate is still far off, Look, I agree that this election should be about other issues and it behooves Hillary to make her case on these (which she does, and better than in the handwaving abstractions that Trump uses).

Your comment boils down to this: you confine Trump's flaws to the way he deals with women and you are prepared to overlook them for what you perceive as the greater good of the nation.

As if that were not bad enough, Trump's sexism is but one part of how he has in general abused others, whether women, ethnic and religious minorities, customers, clients, contractors, employees or business adversaries. There's just too much there to overlook.

It all boils down to power.

If you get President Trump you will get the unsavory human being that has stepped on people for his entire career. I don't have enough faith that checks an balances would curb Trump's inner Mussolini from stifling opposition. He has a history of using lawsuits or the threat of them to intimidate business opponents. It's no stretch to expect that his AG would be busy doing the same kind of thing.

President Trump will ensure that Walmart's profits rise: Racial profiling, and building that wall, will substantially reduce shoplifting.  Fining employees who get pregnant out of wedlock will produce an income stream.  'Renegotiating' prices at checkout, a Trump administration program "designed to encourage employees to use their initiative," is expected to yield 1% to 2% extra profit because cashiers are forbidden to 'renegotiate' prices down. And of course, corporate tax rates will come , so under Trump, Walmart will be OK.  Unless they stop selling guns.

Give a man enough rope to hang himself:

Trump's psychotic tirades are killing him more than anything Hillary can say.
Chozick is the prime purveyor of "clouds and shadows", basically laughable opinion journalism based on the dated hostile narrative rather than facts.

Dear Ms. Chozick,
Please stop this nonsense. What a stretch of a story with no background facts. Are you trying to give a "balanced" view?
Well said.

This piece is disappointing.

First of all, referencing Wikileaks hacked material...why? What purpose does it serve other than to reward those who are breaking into computer systems at the behest of another government, in order to influence our election.

Your piece didn't need it. Was it a case of your editor standing over you, telling you had to incorporate something from Wikileaks?

You're making an assumption that Clinton can't call out Trump for his horrendous, scathing put-downs of women, because Bill Clinton had past affairs. Bill can handle his own problems...if Clinton isn't dancing the Trump two-step, perhaps she doesn't want to get down into the dirt.

As for young women voting for Sanders...all the young women I know voted for Clinton. Perhaps if you looked behind the mega-speeches Sanders put on in college towns, you might remember that people differ...not everyone votes the same.

It's almost as if you're desperately trying to find something to criticize Clinton for amidst the melt-down that is Trump, in order to meet some arbitrary 'fairness'.

Well don't. Just enjoy the fact that we have one sane, experienced candidate who doesn't scare the hell out of us. And as an added bonus: she'll be our first women President.
Clinton is not stepping on Trump's bad news, which is stepping on Clinton's bad news.

It's amazing to me that Trump and his supporters denounce how partisan the NYT is when there are articles such as this one. As virtually all have commented so far there is absolutely no reason for Clinton to get into the fray on this one more than she already has.
Why o why do you want to take Hillary down? I'm so tired of your critiques of her personality and minor failings. Get real and think for just a moment of the orange alternative for women.
Correction...that was Napoleon with the never interrupt quote
Remember: Being The NY Times means never having to go a day without hinting that Hillary Clinton is deeply compromised somehow.

Whether you'r talking about Melania and Donald, or, Hillary and Bill, it's their respective marriages and not primarily anyone else's business how they work things out between each other.

Personally, I wish all women would "throw the bums out" when their husbands cheat, speak of doing crummy things to other women, and so forth. But, that's not the way things work in marriages with many years together, kids, family, etc. And, yeah, our first instinct is to circle with wagons and start shooting... We're not thinking maybe the Indians have another reason to be there...

As for what Hillary can or should say while Donald hacks away at his own reputation of being "a straight shooter and telling it like it is..." Hmmm. Probably better to let him keep talking about him; eventually more people will get tired of him and ask:

"Yeah, but what about nuclear bombs, global warming, rising sea levels, kids failing in school, so many shot dead with so many guns, distant wars killing so many hundreds of children, millions about to lose their jobs to self-driving cars, and robots that can do inventories, sell tickets, and do customer service work on the phone...?"
If they go low, we go high. Let him stew in his own juice. Enough said.
